discoveredAssets: localhost:3000 (127.0.0.1) - Encoder64 Blog - PHP 7.4.33 / Apache 2.4.54 - Port 3000 OPEN
http://localhost:3000/ - Homepage with Base64 encoded flag: {I'm_a_Script_Kiddie}
http://localhost:3000/index.php - Main blog listing page with pagination (?page=n)
http://localhost:3000/contact.php - Contact form (GET/POST) - Accepts name, email, message fields
http://localhost:3000/post.php?id={id} - CRITICAL: LFI vulnerable - successfully exploited to read /etc/passwd and Apache logs
http://localhost:3000/posts/ - Blog post files directory (403 Forbidden listing, but files accessible)
http://localhost:3000/posts/EternalBlue.php - Direct access to post file (bypasses routing)

targets.objective: Exploit confirmed Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerability: Test for Remote Code Execution via log poisoning (inject PHP in User-Agent â†’ include Apache logs), attempt to read sensitive files (/etc/shadow, SSH keys, config files, database credentials), test PHP wrappers for source code disclosure, attempt RCE via data:// wrapper or expect:// if available, test for filter bypass techniques
targets.rationale: CRITICAL CONFIRMED VULNERABILITY: Successfully exploited LFI - read /etc/passwd and Apache access logs. The id parameter accepts path traversal (../../../../) without sanitization. Log poisoning vector confirmed (can read /var/log/apache2/access.log) enabling potential RCE. This is the highest priority target as it provides direct path to system compromise

targets.objective: Test POST form for all injection vulnerabilities: Stored/Reflected XSS in name/email/message fields, SQL injection if data stored in database, NoSQL injection, Email header injection, Command injection if email sent via shell commands, CSRF attacks, HTML injection, SSTI (Server-Side Template Injection), XXE if XML processing, file upload bypass if any upload functionality, business logic flaws in form validation
targets.rationale: HIGH RISK: POST form accepts three user input fields (name, email, message) with no visible security measures. Multiple injection vectors possible. If form data is stored, could enable stored XSS. If email functionality uses system commands, could lead to command injection. No CSRF tokens observed

targets.objective: Test pagination parameter for SQL injection: Time-based blind SQLi, Boolean-based SQLi, UNION-based injection, error-based SQLi, second-order SQLi, test for NoSQL injection if MongoDB backend, IDOR (access unauthorized pages), business logic bypass (negative page numbers, extremely large numbers), information disclosure via error messages
targets.rationale: MEDIUM RISK: Pagination parameter accepts numeric input and queries backend (likely database). Initial SQLi test with single quote returned normal response (may have sanitization), but deeper testing required. Could reveal database structure, leak data, or enable authentication bypass

targets.objective: Test direct file access bypass: Enumerate all post files in directory (predictable naming), test for PHP code execution if files are writable, attempt to access files outside posts directory, test for backup files (.php~, .bak, .old), directory traversal from this context, information disclosure via direct file access bypassing intended security controls
targets.rationale: MEDIUM RISK: Post files directly accessible at /posts/{filename}.php bypassing the intended routing through post.php?id=. This could expose internal application logic, allow direct PHP execution if files are writable/uploadable, or bypass security controls implemented in the routing layer. Directory listing disabled but individual files accessible

targets.objective: Test for client-side vulnerabilities: DOM-based XSS in JavaScript code (visitor counter, search widget), analyze all JavaScript for sensitive data exposure, test for prototype pollution, check for insecure CORS configuration, test for open redirects, clickjacking (no X-Frame-Options), MIME sniffing attacks (no X-Content-Type-Options), session fixation, weak authentication mechanisms
targets.rationale: MEDIUM RISK: Application missing all security headers (X-Frame-Options, CSP, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection). Vulnerable to clickjacking, XSS without CSP protection, and MIME sniffing. JavaScript code manipulates DOM (visitor counter) which could be exploited. No HTTPS/HSTS observed

targets.objective: Enumerate static files and test for information disclosure: Brute force common filenames (backup.zip, db.sql, config.php, .env), test for source code disclosure, attempt directory traversal, test for unrestricted file upload locations, search for sensitive files (credentials, keys, configs), test for direct object references
targets.rationale: LOW-MEDIUM RISK: Static directories exist with directory listing properly disabled (403). However, if predictable filenames exist (backups, config files, source archives), they could be directly accessed. Worth testing for common sensitive file patterns

targets.objective: Test for information disclosure and injection: Reflected XSS if any parameters accepted, SSTI in template rendering, analyze response for sensitive information leakage, test for CRLF injection in headers, parameter pollution, HTTP verb tampering (PUT, DELETE, PATCH), check for exposed comments in HTML source
targets.rationale: LOW RISK: Static content page but should be tested for injection vulnerabilities and information disclosure. Part of comprehensive coverage

targets.objective: Comprehensive security assessment: Session management testing (session fixation, hijacking, weak tokens), authentication testing (even if no visible login - test for hidden admin panels), authorization bypass, business logic flaws, rate limiting bypass, brute force protection, information disclosure in error messages, verbose errors, technology stack fingerprinting for known CVEs (PHP 7.4.33, Apache 2.4.54), test all HTTP methods (PUT, DELETE, PATCH, TRACE, CONNECT), test for HTTP request smuggling, test for subdomain takeover if any subdomains exist
targets.rationale: COMPREHENSIVE TESTING: Full application assessment to identify any vulnerabilities not caught in endpoint-specific testing. Technology stack (PHP 7.4.33, Apache 2.4.54) should be checked against known CVEs. Ensure complete coverage of OWASP Top 10

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerability CONFIRMED in /post.php?id parameter - Successfully exploited to read /etc/passwd and Apache access logs
[CRITICAL] Log poisoning attack vector available - LFI can read /var/log/apache2/access.log enabling potential Remote Code Execution
[HIGH] POST form on /contact.php accepts unsanitized user input (name, email, message) - Multiple injection vectors possible
[HIGH] Direct access to post files via /posts/{filename}.php bypasses intended routing and security controls
[HIGH] Missing all critical security headers: X-Frame-Options, Content-Security-Policy, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection
[MEDIUM] Path traversal confirmed with ../ sequences working across multiple directory levels
[MEDIUM] Base64 encoded string in homepage reveals flag: {I'm_a_Script_Kiddie} - Information disclosure
[MEDIUM] Directory listing disabled (403) but individual files accessible if names are known
[MEDIUM] Pagination parameter ?page= on index.php could be vulnerable to injection attacks
[LOW] No HTTPS/TLS - Application running on plain HTTP on port 3000
[LOW] PHP 7.4.33 and Apache 2.4.54 versions should be checked against known CVEs
[LOW] .htaccess file exists and is protected (403 Forbidden) - proper configuration
